I realize you can find evidence that some Saudis have financed and participated in terrorism, the prime example being Bin Laden. You can find evidence that some Americans have done the same.
First I want to mention briefly that bin Laden is not a Saudi citizen. The kingdom stripped him of his citizenship more than 10 years ago and declared him persona non grata after he tried to overthrow the ruling regime.
 
 As for the parallel you've drawn between American terrorists and Saudi terrorists, it doesn't stand up to scrutiny. No doubt we have terrorists within our borders, but our government brooks no nonsense from home-grown American terrorists, whereas the Saudi royal house has powerful factions that finance and protect terrorist groups.
 
 Surely there are Saudis favorably disposed to the West and who might fairly be considered American allies, but the prevailing view of most Saudis is anti-American, as confirmed in their media and in their schools and mosques. When we ask if the Saudis are friend or foe, our focus should be on the House of Saud, since most Saudis on the street are already antagonistic to the U.S.
 
 Despite rough patches in U.S.-Saudi relations since 9/11, it's no surprise that some in Washington continue to characterize the Saudis as our friends. We have no practical alternative. If the monarchy falls, its replacement is certain to be more hostile to U.S. interests, so we're nearly compelled to remain in bed with a brutal totalitarian regime and hope that the rivalries and intrigues gripping the royal house eventually pan out in our favor. None of this would even matter if the kingdom were not sitting on an ocean of oil, but that's reason enough for the U.S. to want to maintain our long-standing bilateral friendly relations.
 
 Still, there are of major concerns one can point to that underscore the dangers that Saudi policy poses to U.S. security. The most significant perhaps is Saudi Arabia's state religious doctrine, the Wahhabite version of Islamic law. It's the same ideology that drives the fundamentalist militancy of al Qaeda. Indeed, militant Islam thrives in Saudi Arabia, and despite proclamations by the Saudis of being U.S. allies in the war on terror, the country remains a principal supporter of al Qaeda as well as Palestinian terror groups.
 
 Furthermore, the Saudi princes use petro dollars as a way to control religious leaders and keep them at bay, by redirecting their anger outward, against the West. Wahhabism calls for the destruction of the U.S. and rejection of Western values, replacing them with totalitarian Islamist regimes like the one they created in Afghanistan under the Taliban. The Saudis continue to actively support literally thousands of mosques and madrassas around the world, from Pakistan and Indonesia to Western Europe and the U.S.
 
 Now some of the terrorism the Saudis sowed abroad is coming home to roost. The attacks this year within the kingdom are likely related to the raging struggle within the royal house for succession to the throne. The king's illness has left him incapacitated for nearly a decade, leaving the kingdom without the solid authority of a reigning monarch. As a result, the de facto ruler, Crown Prince Abdullah, is unable to innovate reforms or effectively fight terror.
 
 Abdullah's opposition includes defense minister Sultan, interior minister Nayef, and Riyadh governor Salman, among others. Abdullah's declared war on al Qaeda is genuine, but Nayef, as interior minister, is the one responsible for conducting the anti-terror campaign. However, Nayef is still playing a double game, as evidenced by the collusion between the terrorists and Saudi security forces in the attack on the Khobar Petroleum Complex. The attack was designed to scare foreign workers out of the country and sabotage the U.S.-Saudi oil deal to increase production and curb rocketing prices. Al Qaeda's ability to penetrate the well-fortified complex was faciliated by Nayef's ambivalence in confronting the religious extremists.
 
 One can argue the Saudis are our friends, but it's easier to argue just the opposite. The recent half-hearted, self-serving Saudi attempts to cooperate with the U.S. may be too little too late. The longer the royal feuds continue, the less chance there is of stamping out Saudi terror. It's even possible that Abdullah and Nayef will never reach an accommodation, in which case the fall of the House of Saud may come sooner instead of later.
